text: _@pedregon.samantha has joined the channel_
_@luciamariafonsecasoar has joined the channel_

Hi Lucia, please meet Samantha your incredible E-Mentor we've been telling you about :smile:.Â Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or penny-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:

Note: You will not see your match as a "member" in this channel however you can see from the chat history that they have joined/been added :smile:
_@dexter has left the channel_
_@dexter has left the channel_

Hi Samantha! Really nice to meet you! My name is Lucia, I'm 20 and I'm studying 3D animation and modelling at the university of Hertfordshire! I saw that you work at the mill, I really like their work so it is exciting to get to know someone that works there. I would actually be interested in knowing more about how working there is like, if that's something you would like to share? I am mostly interested in modelling and texturing so would be great if you could guide me and help me in those areas in the future. Thank you and excited for this mentorship :)
Hey Lucia!! Great to meeet you as well! :smile:

I am Samantha, I'm 27 and have been working at the Mill doing modeling/texturing for the past 4 years. :slightly_smiling_face: I'd totally love to explain how it's like working here. Is there anything you specifically have questions about for working at The Mill?
Do you have any goals/ideas of where you would want to work or what you'd like to accomplish in the industry? (examples: work on a movie, becoming a creative director, become a senior artist, etc.)
If you don't that's okay, just would help me to help you if I know what your end goal is or if you'd like help deciding that as well :slightly_smiling_face:

I would like to know more about how's the day to day life at the mill. Do you have dailies regularly? And do junior artists get support from senior artists?  Anything else you think it's interesting would be great to know

The film industry is definitely something I want to work on, although advertisement seems also interesting since it's smaller projects and I can have opportunities to work in multiple projects this way. Becoming a director is something that was always in my mind but I don't really know how to follow that route,  so I think becoming a junior artist first and then see where things would lead me would be the way to go I think? If you have any insight on that it would be great!

Yeah day to day life at The Mill can vary. Our work hours are 9am to 6pm, but no one really times when you come in or when you leave. So if you get in at 9:05am, no one is going to get on you for being 5 minutes late. Same thing with going home, as long as you've competed your tasks, met your deadline, and/or no one is waiting on you for something you can leave whenever you'd like. If you need to stay late to work through something though, The Mill provides a free dinner for you.

Every day can be different. Some days are filled with meetings, dailies, or department meetings. Other days you are working on a repetitive mundane tasks like retopoing something or cleaning up a project so it's file size isn't so heavy (that's what I'm doing right now). Then there are days where you have headphones on and are deep into modeling an entire environment or texturing a large asset.

We don't really have junior artists anymore, but when we did they would help support senior artists, and we even have a mentor program so junior artists can be paired up with a more senior artist who can help show them the ropes on things here. When I was a junior artist, I never felt afraid to ask someone for help. All of the senior artists were extremely patient with me and helped me learn things when I had questions about them. Even now, as a mid level artist, I still will have questions on things and the older artists are great and share with me their knowledge still too lol You never stop learning in the job industry, which is why I signed up for this program because I feel I benefited so much when I had a mentor that I want to pay it forward as well.

At the Mill in LA, we will be working on tons of projects at once, and the number of team members for a project varies. You might be on job where it's just two artists, other jobs will have as many as 20 artists on it at once! The timeline for projects range from only having 2 weeks to 6 months, the average being about 2 months from start to finish.

If you were to get into film, that time frame changes drastically. I have never worked in film, but a lot of artists here at The Mill used to. My modeling supervisor worked on Beauty and the Beast modeling/sculpting a shirt for 3 months. Imagine just working on 1 thing for months at a time. That's a lot of time compared to commercials, where we only have maybe two or three weeks.

For your goals, it's normal to not be sure where to go lol To be a director, you have to have the creative mind to see the "Big Picture" of a project, as well as social skills to communicate with clients and get them to want you to direct a commercial for their product/service. As a creative director you have to maintain a professional relationship with clients to keep them coming back to do more work. The more you work with a creative director, the better of an idea you'll have for what their job role is. I'm sure the more you get hands on experience, you'll have a stronger idea of what you'd like to do. :slightly_smiling_face: I know when I first got into this industry I really didn't know what i wanted to do, so understand that it's okay to just go with the flow until you realize what really speaks to you! :slightly_smiling_face:

Btw, I noticed you are in the UK right? When is it convenient for you to come online here? :slightly_smiling_face: I'm on the computer every day for work, so I'm available every weekday as long as I am not crazy busy with work. We don't have to talk everyday, we can even keep it as a once a week thing, whatever suits your schedule! Just let me know what works for you.
Thank you so much for the information and for taking time to actually be on this program

Anytime is fine for me really since I have the app I can respond to the messages easily as long as it is times I'm awake. I may just take a bit longer to respond sometimes because I want to read them with attention. If it's fine with you I could show work in progress of what I'm currently working on maybe every week? Doesn't have to be strict just around that time and also any other questions I might have? Depends what you are fine with as well
Also talking about that, do you by any chances know any good tutorials about texturing in Mari in general? I'm trying to get into it but I feel there's not that many good tutorials online

Of course, I'm excited about this mentoring experience with you! :slightly_smiling_face: And yes, send me any WIP you have whenever you have them, and don't be afraid to ask me questions! I'm hear to help you with anything you aren't confident about or if you need direction or advice! I hope I can do a great job of it. :slightly_smiling_face:
 It's really great to see the kind of work younger artists are able to put out. With more school programs coming out for CG, even with Youtube it's so much easier to learn about this industry than when I was first starting out lol.

And yes I do know some tutorials for Mari! So glad you asked, we actually just passed around at my work last week.
<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCYV54HXYtGR-gHjXuH8UaEQ/videos>
Have you used Mari before or is this your first time trying it out? :slightly_smiling_face:
